channel.title: A question for you "profesionals"
channel.description:
I have recently decided to actualy learn the Java language, and so I thought I would come back to this community and learn a little bit about it while programming my own server.
My question to you all is if I wanted to be good at programming (like memorize commands and stuff like that) do you suggest I learn the some of the actual language first or just learn as I go when developing my server. I want to be able to code like Cocoa or someone else like that because when I played on his server i was amazed at how he could just type in something so quickly off the top of his head and then something amazing would come up in the server.
I know it will take a lot of hard work and practice but what do you all think the best way is to be able to code a server like that? In the future I hope to code games using java like MINECRAFT!!!!

item.title: A question for you "profesionals"
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:21, topic:383172”][quote author=ytuio9 link=topic=478949.msg3507834#msg3507834 date=1298271506]
Memorizing comes by application, though
[/quote]

Yes, you remember trivial stuff. But if a programmer tells you they never look up things, or look at the docs, then they are either a liar or never write anything more than trivial applications.[/quote]I heard Javafire never used google… :rolleyes:

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:

ytuio9:

Memorizing comes by application, though

Yes, you remember trivial stuff. But if a programmer tells you they never look up things, or look at the docs, then they are either a liar or never write anything more than trivial applications.

item.title: A question for you "profesionals"
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Programmers don’t ‘memorize’ code, commands, or anything else like that. This is what we use documentation for, in the case of java, that usually comes in the form of javadocs. You do need to learn programming concepts and the like though, so I’d recommend you start out with something like this:

http://download.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/getStarted/index.html

Read full topic

item.title: A question for you "profesionals"
item.dc:creator: @rash Rash
item.description:
@rash wrote:

[quote=“b b0yz 4, post:3, topic:383172”]Vain:
Well I want to learn java while having fun and doing something…therefore moparscape…

Arrays:
So lets say I want to make a command so the door opens perfectly when i click on it. You suggest I read the code involving the door and learn how to fix it?[/quote]

Do exactly what arrays said.

item.title: A question for you "profesionals"
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

krackkid:

RSPS don’t use java…They use jaba.

What is this jaba that you speak of?

In all seriousness you shouldn’t try creating a game to learn java. Most programmers created a calculator as their first program. Not a server parsing incoming packets and such. Just my theory. I don’t program much though…

Read full topic

item.title: A question for you "profesionals"
item.dc:creator: @IlikeArrays IlikeArrays
item.description:
@IlikeArrays wrote:

READ READ READ READ READ READ JAVA JAVA JAVA JAVA JAVA

Then after you read a lot…

ATTEMPT ATTEMPT ATTEMPT

Seriously it is a lot easier to read code then to type it. Actually attempting makes the difference.

Read full topic
